data.title: Marbachegg panorama trail to Kemmeriboden
data.meta_description: Easy one way hike near Lucerne Switzerland leading to an alpine dairy, then down the mountain through alpine pastures.
data.text:
Photo story of trail

1. Riding up gondola to Marbachegg

Here is the Marbachegg gondola stations. Buy tickets here.

Four people fit in each gondola car. It’s a short ride to the top.

The gondola station at the top.

Restaurant at the top of the gondola. We had a quick coffee/cocoa & croissant before heading on the trail.

Here’s what the gondola station looks like after you are on the hike. It’s at the top of the lift.

2. Riding the Mountain go-carts

Right at the gondola you’ll find the go-carts. We paid here in cash for one ride each.

Here is the wooden track you ride down.

The track gets quite steep at times so stay in control.

At the bottom of the track, you get off your cart. The attendant sets the cart in the correct position then you get on the cart again. The attendant hooks the tow bar to your cart and you hold the handlebars as you ride to the top.

3. Starting the trail

Near the carts and gondola station, you’ll see this trail sign. Follow signs to Imbrig and Kemmeriboden Bad. You are also on the green 65 Grenzpfad Napfbergpfad.

The trail starts on this “road”.

The path descends these stairs to the first picnic area near that little pond.

Now down a big grassy hill.

Looking back up to Marbachegg.

Join the road and turn left following the road.

At this farm, the trail branches left off the road for a bit. We missed this turn off and continued on the road. Don’t worry if you miss it too because the trail joins back with the road after a few minutes.

Lovely views down the valley.

Passing by adorable farm houses.

The road is leading close to those peaks, the Schrattenfluh range.

Now very close to the peaks. Take lots of pics here.

You’ll see this sign for Alp Imbrig. It’s a five min detour uphill to the alpine dairy, which has a cafe selling hot and cold food. There’s a menu posted on the sign to help you decide.

To continue hiking, keep following the road as it curves to your right.

You’ll pass another picnic area in a shady spot. It has a nice view the other direction

At this fork, go right following signs to Kemmeriboden Bad.

After this farm, you leave the road and follow a footpath for the rest of the way down the mountain.

Traversing and slowly making your way down.

You will pass through a few farms on the way.

At this section, you’ll see a Danger sign warning of you possible falling rocks over a short section. Just walk quickly through and don’t stop or linger in this section.

There are some steep slopes to the side but the trail is wide and well built.

Despite the number of meters you have to descend, the walk down was milder than expected.

Almost down with the peaks getting farther away.

Emerging from the forest at this parking near the Kemmeriboden bus stop.

If you already have a ticket, just get on the bus. If you don’t have a ticket, you can buy one with coins from the driver. It’s about a 20 mins drive back to the gondola station. If you came here by public transportation, you can stay on this bus to the Escholzmatt, Bahnhof train station. Although the trail was empty, the bus was very crowded on the Sunday afternoon we went, presumably people doing other trails in the area.

FAQ

Can you take dogs on this trail?

Yes, dogs are welcome on this trail and ride free on the gondola. You are expected to keep dogs on the leash, particularly around cattle and other hikers. Please clean up after your dogs waste.

What to wear

This is a mountain hike, so weather and temperatures can change quickly. Dress appropriate to the weather forecast, bringing layers like a fleece and windbreaker/rain jacket as needed. Most of the trail is quite wide and away from tall grass. So for hot days, it’s ok to wear shorts.

Although much of the trail is on a road, the second half is on a dirt footpath with uneven terrain. So I suggest hiking shoes with good tread. I found hiking sticks helpful on the steep downhill sections on the last few km of the hike.

For sunny days, make sure to bring sunscreen, sun hat, and sunglasses. Bring at least 1 L of water per person. There are no fountains but you can buy drinks at the mountain restaurants.

What to bring

Although you can buy refreshments at the restaurants along the way, I suggest bringing minimum 1 L of water per person and snacks.
